CTOD Importance/Applications of CTOD: Critical CTOD as a measure of toughness. Exp. measure of driving force. Multiaxial fracture characterization. Specimen size requirements for K I c and J I c testing. c SMA 2000 MIT Fatigue and Fracture 18

0 d n is a strong function of n, and a weak function of 0E. Plane Strain: d n 0 : 3 , 0 : 65 0:65 for n ! 1 Plane Stress: d n 0:5 , 1:07 1:07 for n ! 1 c SMA 2000 MIT Fatigue and Fracture 16

Derivation J Integral Continued
Z du M @ u d , w dy , T s da S @ x J J represents the rate of change of net potential energy with respect to crack advance (per unit thickness of crack front) for a non-linear elastic solid. J also can be thought of as the energy ow into the crack tip. Thus, J is a measure of the singularity strength at the crack tip for the case of elastic-plastic material response. SMA 2000 MIT Fatigue and Fracture c 8

J Integral Derivation Continued We will use the following variables: a = crack length. S = a curve linking the lower and upper crack surfaces. d s = an element of arc on this curve. T= traction vector on this curve dened in relation to an outward normal unit vector, i.e. T n . u= corresponding displacement vector. We consider a small strain analysis; we neglect any deformation-induced blunting of crack tip. SMA 2000 MIT Fatigue and Fracture c 4

Ka n d J-Dominance Consider a low strength steel with 0 350 MPa, K I c 250 MPapm and E 210 GPa. What are the Minimum specimen size requirements for valid K I c and J I c measurements? c SMA 2000 MIT Fatigue and Fracture 22

CTOD The variation in crack tip opening displacement t or (CTOD) for different material response is depicted below: The crack tip opening displacement depends on distance from the crack tip. We need an operational denition for CTOD. c SMA 2000 MIT Fatigue and Fracture 14

J Integral Derivation Continued For proportional loading J 2 deformation theory and J 2 ow theory (incremental theory of plasticity) give results that are comparable (i.e. for monotonic loading, stationary cracks). Not appropriate for situations where signicant unloading occurs. The total mechanical potential energy of the cracked body is u M u e + u app This represents the sum of the stored strain potential energy and the potential energy of the applied loading. SMA 2000 MIT Fatigue and Fracture c 6
J Integral Derivation Continued Consider the path around the crack tip shown below: SMA 2000 MIT Fatigue and Fracture c 3

Fracture Elastic Plastic Previously, we have analyzed problems in which the plastic zone was small compared to the specimen dimensions (small scale yielding). In todays lecture we present techniques for analyzing situations in which there can be large scale yielding, and determine expressions for the stress components inside the plastic zone. We will begin with a discussion of the J integral. SMA 2000 MIT Fatigue and Fracture c 1
J-Dominance c SMA 2000 MIT Fatigue and Fracture 21
J-Dominance Just as for the K eld, there is a domain of validity for the HRR ( J -based) elds. c SMA 2000 MIT Fatigue and Fracture 19

HRR eld We now consider the Hutchinson, Rice, Rosengren (HRR) singular crack tip elds for elastoplastic material response. (Recall Williams solution assumes linear elastic material behavior). Assume: Pure power law material response:
n
0 0 = material constant, 0 = reference yield strength, n = strain hardening exponent, 0 reference yield strain 0E. For linear elastic material n 1, for perfectly plastic response n 1. c SMA 2000 MIT Fatigue and Fracture 12

J Integral Derivation Continued Consider two different paths around the crack tip: c SMA 2000 MIT Fatigue and Fracture 10

J Integral Derivation The J integral is a line integral (path-independent) around the crack tip. It has enormous signicance in elastic-plastic fracture mechanics. Key Reference: J. R. Rice, Journal of Applied Mechanics , 1968. (Related works: Eshelby, Progress in Solid State Physics 1956; Sanders, Journal of Applied Mechanics , 1960; Cherepanov, International Journal of Solids and Structures , 1969) SMA 2000 MIT Fatigue and Fracture c 2

CTOD The denition of t is somewhat arbitrary since the opening displacement varies as the crack tip is approached. A commonly used operational denition is based on the 45 construction depicted below (see C.F . Shih, JMPS , 1982). c SMA 2000 MIT Fatigue and Fracture 15
